headline: Good salary and benefits, unfortunately discrimination runs rampant within the organization
pros: Salary is relatively on par with the financial industry. I was based in Ontario, however my team was based in Quebec. Opportunities for high achievers are accessible to most, that said the challenges with politics (internal & external) are quite evident.
cons:
Generally speaking most educated and civilized people will act with professionalism and respect to those who are different. Even if they didn’t agree with the person’s views, opinions or existence, they act cordially. For the most part, the majority of my former colleagues are kind and amazing human beings. That said, there is a large population within the organization that proudly displays their xenophobic behaviour, almost to the extent it could be viewed as ‘hostile’. 

I am a visible minority and a proud Canadian. My first language is English and I was born in Ontario. Many people in this organization will make you feel inadequate because you’re “Anglo” or because of the colour of your skin. It has gotten to the point that I developed a serious phobia of travelling to QC for work. 

I have many experiences over the years but the most painful one was when a colleague refused to shake my hand or acknowledge me during my work trip to QC, they don’t hesitate to show you how they feel about you. 

No salary, benefits or perks was worth feeling like a second class citizen on a regular basis. I know this review seems harsh, but believe me, it’s the truth.  I was sad to leave the many relationships I’ve built, but at the same time was relieved that I didn’t have to subject myself to another xenophobic incident.

headline: Glad that I worked there
pros:
I worked in Desjardins as a junior actuary. Overall, I was very happy with my experience in Desjardins.
 
- Working environment: Professional and very friendly working environment, and mazing colleagues. My mentor and manager was great. As someone writing exams, it was nice to have people from work to support you. Additionally, it was nice that managers (at least mine) understood your situation and would plan your agenda accordingly. 

- Professional growth: For me, it was a good place to grow as an actuary. It is an environment where people encourage you to gain more "tools" in your "toolbox". Communication with your mentor and your manager about your professional goals and your plan on how to achieve these goals are very important. Various opportunities to explore other aspects of insurance business other than actuarial work. 

- Work-life balance: I guess this is a case-by-case scenario because it was depend on the project and the manager. For me, my experience was great. Always felt being challenged at work, but my work never asked me to sacrifice unnecessary time. (What else you can ask for nowadays?)
cons: I've left long ago, so it was not fair to leave any comments here regarding the Cons

headline: Comme ci, comme ca
pros:
- Easy work / life balance. People generally start work between 8 & 9 but by 5:00 the office is a ghost town. (Internal tech support shuts down at 5:00 as I found out when I called them late one day.)
- People are generally very nice.
- Some people have worked there for decades. I'm not sure this is necessarily a "pro", but it's interesting.
- Like any other large corporation, there's a focus on cost control but if you can justify an expense, there won't be any huge pushback.
cons:
- There are a bewildering number of silos in the company. Any large corporation has silos; but at Desjardins there seem to be silos for no particular reason.
- The company is solidly based in Quebec. That's actually kind of neat, but the problem is that many people speak only French and solutions tend to be French-based. If you're based in the province of Quebec, this makes sense. But Desjardins has stated that a major goal is to expand westwards. This will never be realized successfully if the company is insistently stuck in French mode. Don't get me wrong - I like the French language and I think it's neat working in a company where French is as prevalent as it is. But the language of business is English and having people (in HR for example or in tech support) who only speak French is not an advantage.
- Here and there, there are bright managers who shine and provide direction. Overall though there's very little top-down direction and hardly any ownership. HR is essentially non-existent. Building management is centred in Montreal, even for offices that are in Ontario. Want the heat raised or lowered? Fill out a form (in French) and email it to someone who sits 600km away.
- Because of this lack of ownership / accountability, it's really easy for people to not do anything and let issues fester. Creating forward momentum is something you need to dig deep and find within yourself to keep pushing forward on things.

Gets you out of the typical office lifestyle, which can be great for your mental wellbeing.  Although it may be tough it does allow for quick advancement within the industry.
cons: Freedom can also be your downfall as you have no specific schedule or responsibilities (self-employed basically).  Must be a prolific networker, work hard to get your name out there and doing the tough job (prospecting), if this stuff makes you uncomfortable then it isn't for you.  Can lack direction for new recruits who are strangers to the financial services industry.
